reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s practical recommendation in section 5 (weight decisions toward scenario (3) rather than power-seeking under scenario (1)), not the core descriptive claims about convergence/trade/threats. So centrality is moderate: if successful it weakens a main actionable takeaway, but doesn’t collapse the essay’s broader analysis. The dual-use/attack-surface point is a real concern: institutions that lower transaction costs and improve commitment can also lower the cost of extortion and make threats more scalable, which the essay itself treats as potentially value-destroying. However, strength is limited because (i) the essay already foregrounds threats and emphasizes preventing them, so the critique is partly “priced in,” and (ii) section 5’s recommended high-impact work is not explicitly “build moral-trade infrastructure” (it’s broader: improving survival/flourishing), so the critique relies on a somewhat contestable mapping from “scenario (3) actions” to “cooperation-enabling bargaining infrastructure.” The critique is mostly correct in substance and logically coherent, with minor overreach in implying the authors’ recommendation commits them to threat-enabling institutional work. It is clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: Cooperation infrastructure enables threats and extortion under adversarial scenarios
